Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Automatic High Pressure Physisorption Analyzer for the Creation of a Physical Adsorption Laboratory
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Chemistry Major Research Instrumentation Program, Professor Rolando Roque-Malherbe from Universidad Del Turabo and colleagues Agustin Rios, Anastacio Emiliano and Cesar Lozano will acquire an automatic high pressure physisorption analyzer. The proposal is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) metal organic frameworks for methane storage; (b) Prussian blue analogues for small molecules separation from gas flows; and (c) pore size augmented nitroprussides for carbon dioxide storage.

A high pressure physisorption analyzer takes advantage of the very weak attractive interactions between molecules, which arise from so-called van der Waals interactions. In general, high pressure is applied to a gas in contact with a solid substrate. As the pressure increases, the gas molecules are attracted to various degrees by the substrate. Under appropriate conditions, these weak interactions allow separation of gases. If additionally the pores of the substrate are manipulated, the interactions may increase and such solids may be used to store gases. Useful examples are those of carbon dioxide, which may contribute to global warming and may serve as feedstock for chemical reactions under concentrated conditions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Four Hispanic graduate students toward the PhD degree participated in the project; two of them, Christymarie Rivera and Frances N. Lugo graduated in June 2015, under the mentorship of Dr. Rolando Roque Malherbe; Their dissertations were entitled “Synthesis, Characterization and Thermodynamic Study of Carbon Dioxide Adsorption on Akaganeite and Metalorganic Frameworks (Christymarie Rivera) and “Synthesis, Characterization and Physical Adsorption of CO2 in Cd, Ni, and Zn nitroprusides and Ca, Mg hexacyanoferrate (II)” (Frances Lugo Alvarado); Lucas Hernandez Colón is working on the dissertation “Synthesis and Characterization of Covalent Triazine Frameworks with Potential CO2 and CH4 Adsorption Capacity” , under the mentorship of Dr. Anastacio Emiliano, and Carlos Deliz is working on the dissertation “Catalysis in Environmental Application: Carbon Monoxide Emission Converter by Osmium and Platinum Supported on Titanium Oxide”,  under the mentorship of Dr. Santander Nieto, these two students are expected to graduate in June 2017. A syllabus for the course “Application of Advanced Physical Chemistry Methods to Adsorption Processes (CHEM-991)” was developed by Dr. Carlos Olivo Delgado. Two peer reviewed papers are expected to be submitted for publication by June 2017, as products of the dissertation work of Lucas Hernández Colón and Carlos Deliz; a total of four dissertations would be produced during the project entire life. A total of nine Hispanic undergraduate students, under the mentorship of Dr. Agustin Rios (Alexandra González Burgos, Antonio Espinoza, Estefani Mercado Estrella, Marian Ríos, and Raymond Garcia), Dr. Anastacio Emiliano (Angel Echevarría, Fernando Márquez, and Taylor Laboy), Dr. César M. Lozano (Edison Caraballo), and a Hispanic laboratory technician (Ramón Polanco Estrella) participated in the project. Seven faculty members participated in the project, Rolando Roque (former PI), Anastacio Emiliano (PI, former co-PI), Agustín Ríos (co-PI), César Lozano (co-PI), Carlos Olivo (collaborator), Santander Nieto (collaborator), and Lisandro Cunci (Collaborator). The University of Puerto Rico at Mayaguez and the CIMAV (Spanish acronym for Centro de Investigaciones en Materiales Avanzados) Institute at Mexico were Hispanic-serving collaborating institutions; Dr. Oswald N. C. Uwakweh, from UPR-Mayaguez collaborated with obtaining and interpreting adsorption data for a published paper; the CIMAV Institute at Mexico served as contact for the use of the synchrotron facilities by Frances Lugo at Stanford, CA.
